awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing Laurentide Ice Sheet Climate Response and Younger Dryas Trigger with Glacial Varves
awd_abstract_narration:
This project has two objectives. 1) Document the response of the former ice sheet that covered the North American mid-continent to rapid climate changes that occurred at the end of the last ice age. Such a record enhances our ability to predict the response of ice sheets to modern climate change. 2) Test the role of increased freshwater influx to the Atlantic Ocean as a possible trigger for these rapid climate changes, specifically the cold interval known as the Younger Dryas. Modern freshening in the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans has raised concerns that global warming driven increases in glacier runoff could trigger climate cooling. To evaluate models that use this event to assess the future response of the Atlantic Ocean to predicted freshening, the connections (if any) between freshwater discharge and routing before and during the Younger Dryas need to be resolved.

The primary records that will be generated are varve thickness datasets from a large glacial lake, proximal to the former ice sheet. Glacial varves are yearly sediment couplets that appear similar to tree rings, and as such provide an annually resolvable record of how climate affected the ice sheet. The varves will be recovered by coring sediments from many lakes, spanning a broad region west of Lake Superior. By matching thickness patterns between all sites, a 5000+ year time series is anticipated. Working in collaboration with staff at Voyageurs National Park (Minnesota), this work will be showcased for the general public via a permanent indoor exhibit on varves as records of climate and environmental change.

por.por_cntn:
Predicting how the Greenland and Antarctica ice sheets will respond to the planet's changing climate is of great importance. Insight into how these major ice sheets may respond can be gained by studying how the Laurentide Ice Sheet behaved during the most recent deglaciation of North America.

The lakes in this study lie within the footprint covered by Lake Agassiz, an enormous glacial lake that developed along the southern margin of the Laurentide Ice Sheet. Using sediment records and high-resolution CHIRP seismic reflection data, this project has developed a 3,500-year record of the Laurentide Ice Sheet behavior at the end of the Pleistocene. During this period, the global climate exhibited shifts, both warming and cooling, that are known as the Bolling-Allerod and Younger Dryas.

Varves, annual couplets of silt and clay deposited in glacial lakes, form much of the sediments found in these lakes. They document increasing rates of ice retreat during the Bolling-Allerod warming, followed by ice-margin readvance and slower retreat during the Younger Dryas. That the ice sheet behaved this way to the changing climate is not surprising, what is surprising, is the lag, by hundreds of years, of the response relative to the record from the Greenland ice cores. The high-resolution varve record will help test models of paleo-ice sheet behavior, and provide calibration data sets useful for predicting future ice-sheet response in a warming world.

Over its' lifetime, Lake Agassiz's size, water level, and outlet fluctuated in response to changes in the position of the ice-margin.  Data acquired for this project have led to new insights on the timing and number of water level changes for this system, something that has been the subject of debate and public interest for decades. 

Measurements of varve thickness document that at times during the ice-margin's retreat; sedimentation rates in glacial Lake Agassiz were very high. These produced thick packages of sediment that were prone to remobilization and transport. The high-resolution seismic data collected for the project document numerous mass transport deposits. Many of these appear to have been the result of remobilization events triggered by abrupt lake level fall. Other mass transport deposits appear to be the result of seismic shaking that triggered the collapse and remobilization of unstable sediment accumulated on the flanks of the lake basin. Although the region is not considered to be seismically active today, during and shortly after the deglaciation of the region, seismic activity in the area was probably significantly higher due to the rebound of the Earth's crust as the load associated with the ice-sheet dissipated.

The seismic data collected for the project have provided impactful experiential learning opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Minnesota - Duluth through multiple mechanisms, including seismic interpretation exercises in courses and for individual research projects.
